titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Daisy Chase Russell (1895-1990) was a graduate of Whitworth College, Spokane, Washington, and studied at Biblical Seminary in New York before going to Ethiopia as a missionary. Her husband was Fred Lawrence Russell, a graduate of the State College of Washington. The Russells served as missionaries for the Board of Foreign Missions, working primarily in Ethiopia. They were first stationed in Dembi Dollo in the Sayo district, then in Addis Ababa, where Mr. Russell was in charge of the mission office. They returned to the United States between 1936 and 1943, when Ethiopia was occupied by Italy. During part of this time, the Russells worked among American Indians in the Northwest. When they returned to Ethiopia, they were stationed in Addis Ababa and then sent to Maji, where they opened a new station. They retired in 1961.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of approximately 40 black and white glass slides. Subjects include village scenes, patients in a medical clinic, buildings, portraits of individuals and group photographs, and a procession.

accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is restricted; please contact the holding institution for details.
